config.question: Why were Carnegie’s views about the rights of workers contradictory in nature?

choices.content: He professed to believe in defending the rights of workers to form unions and encouraged them to use strikes to achieve their goals.
He supported capitalists in preventing the formation of unions, but he worked toward providing his workers with health facilities.
While he supported capitalists in preventing the formation of unions, he paid his workers high wages.
He professed to believe in defending the rights of workers, but he paid his own workers low wages and disliked unions.

answer_3.response: Consider This: Throughout the nineteenth century, employers opposed unions. “I have always had one rule,” said an executive of U.S. Steel. “If a worker sticks up his head, hit it.” See L.O. 18.2 What were the main characteristics of the new steel and oil industries?
